===Etymology===
From {{etyl|ltc|ja|sort=やしゃ}} {{m|zh|夜叉|tr=yæ<sup>H</sup> cha?}}, itself a transliteration of {{etyl|sa|ja|sort=やしゃ}} {{m|sa|यक्ष}}.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref>

===Pronunciation===
{{ja-pron|やしゃ|acc=a|acc_ref=NHK|y=go}}

===Noun===
{{ja-noun|やしゃ|hhira=やしや}}

# [[yaksha]], a broad class of nature [[spirit]]s or minor [[deity|deities]] who appear in [[Hindu]], [[Buddhist]], and [[Jain]] mythology. May be male or female, benevolent or malevolent.
# {{lb|ja|sort=やしや'|Buddhism}} in Buddhism, [[yaksha]]s are held to be [[follower]]s of {{m|ja|毘沙門天|tr=Bishamonten||Vaiśravaṇa, the chief of the Four Heavenly Kings}}, and guardians of the [[north]]
# {{lb|ja|sort=やしゃ|figurative}} a [[demon]]
#: {{ja-usex|あの女の子は怒るとまさに'''夜叉'''のようだよ。|^あの おんな の こ は おこる と まさ に '''やしゃ''' の よう だ よ。|When that girl gets angry, she's a real '''demon'''.}}

====Idioms====
{{der-top|Idioms}}
* {{ja-r|夜叉が馬を見たよう|やしゃ が うま を みた よう}}: "like when the yaksha saw the horse" → an expression of extreme happiness, from a story of a yaksha who lost his horse
{{der-bottom}}
